Unfortunately irregularities in the plasma and thermal losses have prevented a continuous sustained reaction.In inertial confinement a tiny container of cryogenic hydrogen fuel is ablated and heated by a powerful laser array in a fashion analogous to a tiny hydrogen bomb. The repeated fusion of a steady stream of these tiny pellets would create a controlled sustained flow of energy.Ironically one of the features of fusion reactions that helps make thermonuclear bombs practical is a potential barrier to practical fusion power generation.The highly energetic neutrons emitted from fusion can destroy the structural integrity of reactor materials and even render them temporarily radioactive.Since controlled fusion systems have so far failed to operate for prolonged periods they haven't yet had to face this problem.A second issue with intense neutron flux is that it can be used to generate plutonium and tritium for nuclear weapons production.Such issues mean that fusion power may not prove to be the “clean, endless” source of electricity that some proponents believe.
